articles.headline: A Race for Cash at A.I.G. as Ratings Are Downgraded
articles.snippet: A.I.G. raced to arrange a $75 billion line of credit after credit agencies cut their ratings on its debt.
articles.abstract: A.I.G. raced to arrange a $75 billion line of credit after credit agencies cut their ratings on its debt.
articles.lead_paragraph: Major credit ratings agencies downgraded the American International Group late Monday, worsening its financial health, as Federal Reserve officials and two leading investment banks were in urgent talks to put together a $75 billion line of credit to stave off a crisis at the company.
articles.byline: By Mary Williams Walsh and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: A Sense That Wall St.’s Boom Times Are Over
articles.snippet: Wall Street has gone through tough times before, but some doubt the likelihood of a quick rebound this time.
articles.abstract: Wall Street has gone through tough times before, but some doubt the likelihood of a quick rebound this time.
articles.lead_paragraph: The old Wall Street is giving way to a new one.
articles.byline: By Louise Story and Edmund L. Andrews

articles.headline: Wall St. in Worst Loss Since ’01 Despite Reassurances by Bush
articles.snippet: Investors suffered their worst losses since the terrorist attacks of 2001, and government officials raced to prevent the financial crisis from spreading.
articles.abstract: Investors suffered their worst losses since the terrorist attacks of 2001, and government officials raced to prevent the financial crisis from spreading.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  — In another unnerving day for Wall Street, investors suffered their worst losses since the terrorist attacks of 2001, and government officials raced to prevent the financial crisis from spreading.

articles.headline: In Candidates, 2 Approaches to Wall Street
articles.snippet: John McCain pointed to greed on Wall Street, and Barack Obama linked problems to lax regulation.
articles.abstract: John McCain pointed to greed on Wall Street, and Barack Obama linked problems to lax regulation.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The crisis on Wall Street will leave the next president facing tough choices about how best to regulate the financial system, and although neither Senator Barack Obama nor Senator John McCain has yet offered a detailed plan, their records and the principles they have set out so far suggest they could come at the issue in very different ways.

articles.headline: Life After Lehman Brothers
articles.snippet: Lehman’s bankruptcy filing leaves creditors lining up, employees awaiting word on paychecks and benefits and Lehman’s counterparties rushing to limit their exposure.
articles.abstract: Lehman’s bankruptcy filing leaves creditors lining up, employees awaiting word on paychecks and benefits and Lehman’s counterparties rushing to limit their exposure.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even in the final hour, Dick Fuld could not let go.
articles.byline: By Ben White and Michael M. Grynbaum

articles.headline: On Peninsula in the Storm: No Way Out
articles.snippet: Hundreds of residents of the Bolivar Peninsula in Texas were trapped by high water, hoping that rescue crews would find them.
articles.abstract: Hundreds of residents of the Bolivar Peninsula in Texas were trapped by high water, hoping that rescue crews would find them.
articles.lead_paragraph: HIGH ISLAND, Tex. — First three cages containing seven birds were unloaded from the rescue boat. Then two dogs. Then the figures of a man and a woman uncurled from their huddle at the bottom of the boat and stepped onto dry land.

articles.headline: Georgia Offers Fresh Evidence on War’s Start
articles.snippet: Georgia says intercepted phone calls show it was under invasion by Russia.
articles.abstract: Georgia says intercepted phone calls show it was under invasion by Russia.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article was reported by Dan Bilefsky, C. J. Chivers, Thom Shanker and Michael Schwirtz and written by Mr. Chivers.

articles.headline: Goldman Posts Profit, and Morgan Follows Suit
articles.snippet: Goldman Sachs posted quarterly profit that beat analysts’ expectations, while Morgan Stanley reported profit that was even stronger than Goldman’s.
articles.abstract: Goldman Sachs posted quarterly profit that beat analysts’ expectations, while Morgan Stanley reported profit that was even stronger than Goldman’s.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Wall Street and Main Street struggled to fathom the upheaval sweeping the financial industry, the nation’s two remaining major investment banks went on the offensive on Tuesday, and delivered a rare bit of good news.
